description: From Old French digressiun or disgressiun, from Latin digressio, from digressus + -io (“forming abstract nouns from verbs”), the past passive participle of digredi (“to step away, to digress”), from dis- + gradi (“to step, walk, go”).

entries.meaning: An aside, an act of straying from the main subject in speech or writing.
examples: The lectures included lengthy digressions on topics ranging from the professor's dog to the meaning of life.

entries.meaning: (generally uncountable) The act of straying from the main subject in speech or writing, (rhetoric) particularly for rhetorical effect.
examples: make digression... by way of digression...

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A deviancy, a sin or error, an act of straying from the path of righteousness or a general rule.
examples: Nature...More stronger hadde her operacyonThan she hath nowe in her dygressyon.

entries.meaning: (now rare) A deviation, an act of straying from a path.
examples: By this little digression into Gascony, the Duke had an opportunity... to re-inforce himself with some particular Servants of his.

entries.meaning: (astronomy, physics) An elongation, a deflection or deviation from a mean position or expected path.
examples: This digression [of the Sun] is not equall, but neare the Æquinoxiall intersections, it is right and greater, near the Solstices, more oblique and lesser.
